guide.introduction: Before Chester Carlson invented photocopying, inventors engineered various mechanical devices to replicate images. With a few everyday items found in the home, you can make a pantograph, an image duplicator that allows you to use one pencil to trace an image while another pencil follows its path in parallel to produce a near-identical copy.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Before Chester Carlson invented photocopying, inventors engineered various mechanical devices to replicate images. With a few everyday items found in the home, you can make a pantograph, an image duplicator that allows you to use one pencil to trace an image while another pencil follows its path in parallel to produce a near-identical copy.

Relevant parts
  • Cardboard
  • Pencils
  • Paper
  • Paper clips
  • Paper clip boxes
  • Battery
  • Tape
Tools
  • Marking pen
  • Scissors

steps.title: Cut out and position cardboard strips.

lines.text: You’ll need 4 cardboard strips. Cut 2 strips  measuring 2"×4" and another pair 2"×8", as  shown in the picture.
lines.text_raw: You’ll need 4 cardboard strips. Cut 2 strips  measuring 2"×4" and another pair 2"×8", as  shown in the picture.

lines.text: Place the 2 pairs of strips at  right angles to each other, with the smaller pair  lying on top of the larger pair.
lines.text_raw: Place the 2 pairs of strips at  right angles to each other, with the smaller pair  lying on top of the larger pair.

steps.title: Link cardboard strips with paper clips.

lines.text: Cut 4 holes in the strips and slip 3 paper clips into them, as shown in the picture.
lines.text_raw: Cut 4 holes in the strips and slip 3 paper clips into them, as shown in the picture.

lines.text: Bend up the end of another paper clip, as shown, and tape it to the  top of a paper clip box.
lines.text_raw: Bend up the end of another paper clip, as shown, and tape it to the  top of a paper clip box.

steps.title: Add pencils and secure to table.

lines.text: Cut 2 holes in the image duplicator strips large enough for 2 pencils to fit snugly and stand erect,  as shown in the picture. Turn the cardboard strips over and slip the hole at the end of the left-hand strip over the paper clip that’s taped to the top of the paper clip box.
lines.text_raw: Cut 2 holes in the image duplicator strips large enough for 2 pencils to fit snugly and stand erect,  as shown in the picture. Turn the cardboard strips over and slip the hole at the end of the left-hand strip over the paper clip that’s taped to the top of the paper clip box.

lines.text: Place a second paper clip box under the image duplicator where the 2 large strips meet, to keep it level.
lines.text_raw: Place a second paper clip box under the image duplicator where the 2 large strips meet, to keep it level.

lines.text: To ensure that the drawing pencil (pink) presses against the paper properly, you can add weight to the cardboard strip by taping a AA battery underneath it.
lines.text_raw: To ensure that the drawing pencil (pink) presses against the paper properly, you can add weight to the cardboard strip by taping a AA battery underneath it.

lines.text: Place the original image under pencil A (blue), and a blank sheet of paper under pencil B (pink). Trace the original design with pencil A. Pencil B will follow along, drawing the image on the paper.
lines.text_raw: Place the original image under pencil A (blue), and a blank sheet of paper under pencil B (pink). Trace the original design with pencil A. Pencil B will follow along, drawing the image on the paper.

lines.text: Experiment with different lengths of strips to make larger and smaller copies of the original  design.
lines.text_raw: Experiment with different lengths of strips to make larger and smaller copies of the original  design.
